Pilot China dilarang terbang seumur hidup karena izinkan penumpang berfoto di kokpit
05 Nov 2019, 14:48 by BBC
Seorang pilot di China dilarang terbang seumur hidup karena "membolehkan" penumpang berfoto di kokpit pesawat.
Foto yang viral pada pekan ini tersebut diambil pada Januari dalam penerbangan Air Guilin dari kota Guilin ke Yangzhou.
Foto memperlihatkan seorang perempuan berpose di kokpit dengan makanan terhidang di sampingnya.
Air Guilin menyatakan pilot tersebut telah melanggar peraturan keselamatan udara.


Daxing: Bandara baru di ibu kota China yang berbentuk bintang laut mulai beroperasi


Protes Hong Kong: Ribuan orang duduki bandara, 160 penerbangan dibatalkan


Penerbangan di Cina ditunda setelah nenek lempar koin ke pesawat


'Terima kasih kapten'
Peristiwa ini terjadi pada tanggal 4 Januari dalam penerbangan GT1011 dari dari kota Guilin ke Yangzhou, lapor media pemerintah The Global Times.
Tetapi kemudian menjadi diperhatikan maskapai pada hari Minggu (03/11) karena foto seseorang yang diduga penumpang tersebut mulai tersebar luas di situs micro-blogging Weibo.
Posting memperlihatkan seorang perempuan memperlihatkan tanda V dengan jari-jarinya -- pose yang populer di China -- dengan keterangan, "Terima kasih kapten. Sangat senang."
Perempuan tersebut dikabarkan adalah seorang pramugari yang sedang menjalani pelatihan di satu universitas Guilin, menurut situs berita Chinese News Service.
Air Guilin tidak memerinci apakah foto diambil saat terbang, tetapi pilot China dan para pengamat mengatakan foto tersebut sepertinya diambil saat pesawat sedang terbang.


Di balik meningkatnya penerbangan internasional yang akan banyak singgah di Cina


Lagi, Cina daratkan pesawat di wilayah sengketa Laut Cina Selatan


Pejabat Cina dinonaktifkan karena pukuli pramugari


Larangan terbang seumur hidup
Pilot, yang tidak disebutkan namanya, dilarang menerbangkan pesawat seumur hidup, meskipun tidak jelas apakah dia diberhentikan dari semua jabatan di maskapai.
Air Guilin menyatakan dia "telah melanggar (peraturan) karena mengizinkan personel yang tidak berwenang berada di dalam kokpit".
Menurut Administrasi Penerbangan Sipil China, penumpang tidak diizinkan memasuki kokpit tanpa persetujuan khusus atau dalam keadaan "yang tidak diperlukan".
Anggota staf lainnya yang terlibat dalam kejadian itu juga "diberhentikan tanpa batas waktu" sementara penyelidikan dilakukan.
"Keselamatan 'penumpang' selalu menjadi prioritas Air Guilin. Kami menerapkan pendekatan tanpa toleransi terhadap tingkah laku tidak patut dan tidak profesional apa pun yang dapat berisiko bagi keselamatan penerbangan," kata maskapai China tersebut.
Tahun lalu, maskapai China, Donghai Airlines memberhentikan sementara pilot selama enam bulan dan mencabut sertifikat pengajar penerbangan setelah dirinya mengizinkan istrinya berada di dalam kokpit.

Chinese pilots are banned from flying for life because they allow passengers to take pictures in the cockpit
05 Nov 2019, 14:48 by BBC
A pilot in China is banned from flying for life for "allowing" passengers to take pictures in the aircraft cockpit.
The viral photo this week was taken in January on a Guilin Air flight from Guilin to Yangzhou.
The photo shows a woman posing in the cockpit with food spread beside her.
Air Guilin said the pilot had violated air safety regulations.

Hong Kong protest: Thousands occupy airports, 160 flights canceled


Flight in China was postponed after grandma tossed a coin into the plane


'Thank you captain'
This event occurred on January 4 on a GT1011 flight from from the city of Guilin to Yangzhou, state media reported The Global Times.
But it was later noticed by the airline on Sunday (11/03) because photos of a suspected passenger began to spread widely on the Weibo micro-blogging site.
The post shows a woman showing a V sign with her fingers - a popular pose in China - with the caption, "Thank you captain. Very happy."
The woman reportedly was a flight attendant who was undergoing training at a Guilin university, according to the Chinese News Service website.
Air Guilin did not specify whether the photo was taken while flying, but Chinese pilots and observers said the photo appeared to have been taken while the plane was flying.


Behind the increasing international flights that will stop in China a lot


Again, China landed planes in the disputed territory of the South China Sea


Chinese officials were disabled because they beat up flight attendants


Prohibition of flying for life
The pilot, who was not named, was banned from flying a plane for life, although it was unclear whether he was dismissed from all positions on the airline.
Air Guilin said he "had violated (regulations) for allowing unauthorized personnel to be in the cockpit".
According to the Chinese Civil Aviation Administration, passengers are not permitted to enter the cockpit without special approval or in an "unneeded" state.
Other staff members involved in the incident were also "terminated indefinitely" while the investigation was carried out.
"Safety of 'passengers' has always been Air Guilin's priority. We adopt a zero-tolerance approach to any inappropriate and unprofessional behavior that could pose a risk to flight safety," the Chinese airline said.
Last year, Chinese airline Donghai Airlines temporarily suspended the pilot for six months and revoked the flight instructor's certificate after he allowed his wife to be in the cockpit.
